bibl.title: Letter from Michael E. Connor to Henry Rose Carter, [19--]

div1.p: Connor describes the progress against yellow fever in Mexico. He would like to have Carter's yellow fever articles translated into Spanish.

div1.head: Letter from Michael E. Connor to Henry Rose Carter, [19--]
div1.opener:
R
Connor
Hotel Madrid.
Merida Yucatan Mexico.
My dear Doctor Carter:
div1.p: Your welcome letter of April 7th., reached today.

Dr. Rose had forwarded me a copy of your report to the
Board on the out-break in the Department of Lambayeque and
together with your letter I can visualize the entire sit-
uation. I am hoping that no back fire will take place into
Piura, for if it does, Guayaquil will be re-infected.

I had supposed that Pareja would be appointed after the
sad news of Dr. Becerra's death reached me but I have not
heard of the appointment officially because the mails to
are subject to all sorts of delays.

We are making progress in our work and receiving full
co-operation both from the public and Government. Our
position with the Government has greatly improved in the
last week by their giving us official standing as Delegados,
and this had helped us with the public in general.

I have not seen a case of y.f. since coming here altho
the stegomyia index was quite high, nearly 60%, at the
begining of the work. Of course the local authorities had done some
good work up to the end of 1919 and the results of this
are still effective in certain sections of the city.

Our containers here are tanks, cisterns and the lejia tins?
the cesspools are pouring out culex but I have not been
able to find any stegomyia in any cesspool up to the
present. This is in line with your statement in your lect-
ures of 1914 that they do not breed in cesspools.

The present crisis, which has lasted since 1918 has been
a factor in the control of the disease in Merida as immigra-
tion has practically ceased. The movement of people is out
of the country to other parts of the Republic and especi-
ally to Cuba.

In the event Dr. Rose has not mentioned it to you I would
like you to know that I have suggested to him that our
Board should have your articles on yellow fever, more
especilally those issued by your service in phamphlet form
as well the ones appearing in the Liverpool Journal, trans-
lated into Spanish. I feel that it will be well worth while
as the Doctors in Yucatan and I think in the rest of the
Republic know so very little of the fundamentals of the
disease and especially regarding the habits of the
2.
Stegomyia that the articles referred too would give the
Doctors here a good understanding on the points that are
now very obscure. For instance, they still believe that fumigation
is the prime measure and only undertake together with early
isolation of cases and only undertake anti-larvae measures when
there is an abundance of money to be spent. THe antilarvae
measures was a new thing to them and only now are they be-
gining to accept it. This may seem strange in the view of the
of the generally accepted fact that Yucatan is generally con-
sidered progressive for a Latin country. But it is a fact
never-the-less.

You will be interested to know that the Mayan Code, of the old
civilization of course, makes mention of eidemics of black vomit,
and prescribes remedies. It is saidv that history written at the
time of the landing of the Conquistadores makes mention of an
epidemic of this disease then present amongst the Mayans in the
southeren part of the State. I am on the trail of some supposed
authentic data on this point and am wondering if you would
be interested in having it or perhaps you have it already.

I am writing for this next mail to Doctor Rose suggesting that he
send some one down the West Coast to go over the Southern Ecuador
and to observe conditions in general. Pareja is a good man but
personally I do not feel safe with him, in the first instance he
is related to too many people and in the second he had not grasped
the importance of the sammaler details of the application of
anti-larvae measures, and as you know one must be on the job every
minute of the time to get ahead of the Stegs.

I am glad that Hanson is going to look after the situation in
Peru as against a new man. Is he going to be able to give the
time to the work? You remember when we talked over the situation
in Piura his family affairs were taking up so much of his time
and the work was left to the native men that little or no head-
way was made. This was before you came on the field.
I am naturally anxious and a little worried bout Ecuador and am
asking you to give a little thought to the situation and let
me have your opinion. Should we not have a man down there some-
where, either in Ecuador or working with Hanson.

I am not anxious to return but would gladly do so, if by doing so
if it appeared neceesary. This filed could field could be
placed in charge of a new man as they work is now well organize
and can be carried to a successful conclusion within a reasonable
time.

In a letter from Caldwell he states that the last case in Vera was
Febrary but since that time two cases have shown up in Papantla
some 120 miles north of Vera Cruz. He further reports that co-
operation is excellent and the prospects are good for a success
ful campaign. We are using fish and the reults are ecellent.

With the kindest personal regards and the hope that
you are resting and gaining strength.
Please convey to Miss Carter my sincere good wishes.
